abstract: Katherine Tanney Modern Love column discusses marriages that end when one spouse is diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease; drawing (M)
snippet: Katherine Tanney Modern Love column discusses marriages that end when one spouse is diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: MY mother lived a short drive from the nursing home where, early last year, my father died. Yet she was not with him at the end, nor did she know that her three daughters were in town, gathered round his bedside. As his ability to draw breath slowly ebbed, it is probable that she was at home watching HBO, reading a novel or fixing herself a snack. They were married 47 years -- "all wonderful," to quote my mother, who apparently wasn't counting the last five, when her husband, at 63, became ill with Alzheimer's, her world disintegrated and nothing between them was ever wonderful again.

headline.main: When Mr. Reliable Becomes Mr. Needy
headline.print_headline: MODERN LOVE; When Mr. Reliable Becomes Mr. Needy

abstract: Sizing up potential mates with your Mennonite mom.
snippet: Sizing up potential mates with your Mennonite mom.
lead_paragraph: Cosmic forces have a way of turning up the heat to make us change. Nothing gets your attention, for example, like being ditched by your husband for a guy he met on Gay.com, or having your car totaled by an inebriated youth six days later. Had I done anything to deserve these things? Nothing. I ran six miles a day and made my own yogurt! But when your husband is out canoodling with a dude, the thing to do is pack your bags and head home for a while, even if home is a Mennonite community 3,000 miles away in California and at 43 you’re no longer a practicing Mennonite.

abstract: Hitching from place to place, scrounging cigarettes for my dad.
snippet: Hitching from place to place, scrounging cigarettes for my dad.
lead_paragraph: A few months into my fourth-grade year, in 1987, my father and I hitched a ride with a trucker in Texas, who drove us all the way north to Rochester, Minn., a small city famous for the Mayo Clinic. We were drifters. We hitchhiked even when I was very young, small enough to sleep on top of a suitcase laid on its side. I never knew exactly why we traveled so much, but Dad seemed to have his reasons, and I trusted him.

headline.print_headline: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Sustenance For the Poor

abstract: Jackie Onassis told me to never marry or mix your money. I took her point.
snippet: Jackie Onassis told me to never marry or mix your money. I took her point.
lead_paragraph: I DIDN’T set out to be the breadwinner. I assumed that one day a guy would come along and I would marry him and, well, he’d take care of it. This is one of the fundamental ways in which men differ from women. Growing up, boys assume they’re going to make the money, or at least half the money. Rare is the boy who imagines that marriage will spell a free economic ride and so nurtures his incredible hotness to that end.

abstract: Article on how New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has helped Sharon Fields, former New York City police officer who was first woman to receive department's Medal of Honor; Fields retired on disability after she witnessed fatal shooting of colleague in South Bronx; photos (M)
snippet: Article on how New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has helped Sharon Fields, former New York City police officer who was first woman to receive department's Medal of Honor; Fields retired on disability after she witnessed fatal shooting of colleagu...
lead_paragraph: Sunshine bleached Third Avenue in the South Bronx as Sharon Fields, a 26-year-old rookie police officer, walked her beat on June 15, 1984. Shoppers buzzed along the sidewalks of the commercial strip known as the Hub. She was glad to be out in the spring air. A block away, she spotted Officer Juan Andino, one of the nice guys in the precinct. She walked toward him, looking forward to a chat.

abstract: Now, we live like monks: herbal tea after dinner, the endless seltzer.
snippet: Now, we live like monks: herbal tea after dinner, the endless seltzer.
lead_paragraph: IT was the last night of our honeymoon, and we were making soup with lobster, shrimp and crab — not a meal for someone who, like me, had been sent to the emergency room by a dish of crab Rangoon two weeks earlier. On this trip, I had eaten a lot of shellfish but no crab Rangoon, and the swelling, itching and rapidly closing throat had not returned. I hoped to continue my luck, but I suspected this new allergy was not as limited as I had hoped.

headline.main: We Ate and Drank While the Warning Lights Flashed
headline.print_headline: We Ate and Drank While the Warning Lights Flashed

abstract: Michelle York Lives column on dealing with death of mother with whom she had no relationship because of her refusal to live with abusive stepfather (M)2
snippet: Michelle York Lives column on dealing with death of mother with whom she had no relationship because of her refusal to live with abusive stepfather (M)2
lead_paragraph: My mother was a ghost. She haunted me for 16 years, off and on. Hers was not a traditional haunting. She did not rattle chains or appear beside my reflection in the mirror, though I would have much preferred it that way. She just became invisible. It happened when I was 18. On a brilliant September afternoon, I ran away from home to escape my stepfather. She came home from work to find me stuffing my belongings into my beat-up Chevy Nova. Instead of stopping me, she watched for a moment and then warned that she wouldn't have me in her life if I didn't have him in mine. I was stunned.

abstract: Faith Pullins planned to celebrate her high school graduation at her baby shower, but that day, she went into labor.
snippet: Faith Pullins planned to celebrate her high school graduation at her baby shower, but that day, she went into labor.
lead_paragraph: When Faith Pullins’s son, Jahlil, was born, in July, he was a month premature and weighed three pounds. For four days, he was kept in an incubator and on a respirator. Ms. Pullins’s father, a retired construction worker and a pastor, prayed for Jahlil with his daughter. Finally, Jahlil was able to breathe on his own, and his mother was allowed to hold him.

headline.main: Refreshing a Mother’s Memory With Love and Stories
headline.print_headline: Refreshing a Mother’s Memory With Love and Stories

abstract: Stressed out on Bora Bora.
snippet: Stressed out on Bora Bora.
lead_paragraph: Several months ago I booked a nonrefundable trip to Bora Bora for my honeymoon. The island looked amazing — South Pacific, tiki huts over clear water. Virtually from the moment I bought the tickets, however, the U.S. economy began to plummet. So in January, when we should have been hoarding the rest of our savings, my wife, Lorraine, and I found ourselves embarking on the most extravagant trip we’d ever taken. But that didn’t matter, because after the stress of work and the stress of the wedding, we were looking forward to our reward — two weeks in paradise.

abstract: IT'S a big morning for me: a breakfast date at my place, and I'm cooking. I've scoured the markets and rounded up the best of everything: oranges for zesting, pears for roasting, balsamic for drizzling, goat cheese for crumbling and, to amp up my French toast, a vial of organic Mexican vanilla beans for eviscerating and flecking. I even grated the cinnamon myself. That's just what you do when someone special is coming over.      After completing my knife work, I set the table (folding the napkins in caterer's shapes), float pink peony blossoms in a glass bowl, take a quick shower and put on a well-worn black T-shirt and a good pair of ripped jeans. At 11 a.m. -- right on time -- the buzzer sounds.

headline.print_headline: Race Wasn’t an Issue to Him, Which Was an Issue to Me

abstract: Colum McCann Lives article on meeting woman tending grave in St Petersburg, Russia, cemetery, with same name as fictional character he had invented; drawing (M)
snippet: Colum McCann Lives article on meeting woman tending grave in St Petersburg, Russia, cemetery, with same name as fictional character he had invented; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: I grew up a mile from one of the largest cemeteries in Ireland. As a child, I used to ride my bicycle around its pathways. There were times in the late afternoon that the expanse of Deansgrange seemed entirely mine. Even after growing up in a country where the fabric of myth entangles life and death, I always thought that there was an unnecessary nostalgia attached to the spirit world. Ghosts were unimaginative. Mystery and grace, it seemed to me, arrived far more often in the everyday.

lead_paragraph: He survived conscription in Eritrea, conspired to confront his country’s injustices and faked an emergency to elude the authorities when they discovered his plan. He fled across the African country’s border to Ethiopia and made his way to a refugee camp, braving horrific conditions and rationed food and water for a chance to eventually get to the United States.

abstract: MY first date with Julie did not begin well and ended even worse. For starters, I didn't show. It was Saturday evening of Presidents' Day weekend, and I was drinking gin and tonics and watching hoops in the Telephone Bar on Second Avenue, whiling away the time before I was supposed to meet her at John's Pizzeria just down the block. The next thing I knew it was hours later, and the phone was waking me from my slumber in my apartment on East 12th Street.    I stumbled out of the building and ran to John's, where Julie ended up crying defiantly on the sidewalk, her words lost to me but their meaning clear: never again.

headline.main: Out From Under the Influence
headline.print_headline: MODERN LOVE; Out From Under the Influence

abstract: Trouble in the streets, an afternoon by the sea.
snippet: Trouble in the streets, an afternoon by the sea.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been living in Houston for some time, but I often return to Pakistan to visit my parents. In December, when I arrived in Karachi with my 3-year-old daughter, Minal, the city was spinning with more than the usual winter weddings, parties and reunions. President Musharraf had issued emergency rule to hold back a possible Supreme Court ruling against him, and Benazir Bhutto had returned to Pakistan at her own risk. There had been suicide bombings, the lawyers were battling for restoration of an independent judiciary and parliamentary elections were a few weeks away. My husband, René, wanted me to postpone our trip, but my father wasn’t well, and it was important to go. I assured René I’d do my best to stay away from the political action.

headline.main: Karachi’s Winter Days

abstract: Jason T Shaplen Lives column describes difficult living conditions in North Korea in April 1997, where he was negotiating details of building two safe nuclear reactors to replace old ones; was policy adviser for Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (M)
snippet: Jason T Shaplen Lives column describes difficult living conditions in North Korea in April 1997, where he was negotiating details of building two safe nuclear reactors to replace old ones; was policy adviser for Korean Peninsula Energy Development...
lead_paragraph: It's April 1997, a few days before the birthday of the late Great Leader Kim Il Sung. Majon is cold, so cold that going outdoors would be ludicrous were it not for the fact that it's actually warmer outside than in the building where our hosts have decided we should talk. Instead of negotiating at our usual site near Pyongyang, we accepted the North's invitation to meet at a beach resort in Majon to discuss the details of building two safe nuclear reactors to replace the plutonium-producing ones they mothballed. Heading to the coast sounded like a great idea. But now that our delegation from the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization has arrived, I realize that we should have asked about our accommodations. Unlike the hotel near Pyongyang, which has a revolving restaurant on top, this place has no heating -- none whatsoever. When cold seeps this deep into your bones, it doesn't wash away with a long, hot shower -- especially when there isn't one in your run-down bathroom.

lead_paragraph: Sasha Meza lifted her tiny finger, delicately pointing herself out among her junior high school classmates in the yearbook. Her mother and grandmother shuffled through photographs that were spread across a heavy, dark wood table in the rectory of St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn  pictures of Sasha at the Special Olympics and at her eighth-grade prom, and some from past Easters of Sasha, her brother, Gabriel Samolyuk, now 5, and her sister, Sabrina Samolyuk, now 12.

headline.main: Bringing Home the Wrong Race
headline.print_headline: Bringing Home the Wrong Race

abstract: Lives article by Francisco Martinez, who survived Madrid terrorist train bombing; says he has not been able to think about attack (M)
snippet: Lives article by Francisco Martinez, who survived Madrid terrorist train bombing; says he has not been able to think about attack (M)
lead_paragraph: I got on the train to Madrid early that morning. I live in Alcalá de Henares, a town about 19 miles east of the city. It is famous for being the birthplace of Miguel de Cervantes. The trip takes an hour. I'm 28, and I work in a savings bank. My wife and I have a baby, so I'm often tired these days. As I sometimes do, I fell asleep in my seat. Suddenly I heard an explosion, and then, right away, another. When I opened my eyes, the world around me was bathed in white smoke. I was half asleep and half awake. It was a choking smoke, the kind produced by combustion. Just then I felt something hit me on the head and something else strike my back. I might have been in great pain, but I wasn't able to judge at that moment. All I could think about was escaping the smoke. Someone yelled out, ''Jump through the window!'' By great fortune, I was seated in the front of the train car, right next to a window. I didn't have to break it, because the glass had shattered. It took about 10 seconds for the smoke to clear. I could see three trains, the one I'd been riding in and two others. That was when I realized we had suffered a terrorist attack. My car, well, the windows and doors were gone. One train had the roof blown clear off of it. The next one had been gnarled into a twisted circle. It didn't seem to have a roof. At that point, those of us who could -- three men and I -- jumped back into our car to see if we could do something for the people inside.

headline.main: Live and Forget
headline.print_headline: LIVES; Live and Forget

byline.original: By Francisco Martínez as told to Edward Lewine

abstract: When Jerome W. was 13 years old, he tried to kill himself. He thought that pressures in his life had grown so large that ending his life was the only solution.         He had thought for weeks about how he would do it. Then one day, with family  gathered around him, he simply walked to the window of his fifth-floor apartment in Brooklyn and began to crawl to the ledge. As he poised for the jump, his mother realized what Jerome was doing and pulled him back into the house.

abstract: It was harder than usual to adjust to this new leg.
snippet: It was harder than usual to adjust to this new leg.
lead_paragraph: On my birthday a few years ago, I taught class, called the guy I was sleeping with and then became a cyborg. I didn’t know I was becoming a cyborg. I thought I was just getting a new leg. I’ve had 12 artificial legs in my life. The prosthetist said this leg would think 1,000 times per second about the ground. My parents said if I wanted the new leg, I better act fast. I was being released from their insurance. The guy I was sleeping with, Henry, said the new leg sounded hot, like something out of “Blade Runner.” But I had never seen “Blade Runner.”

abstract: Contributions to the 96th New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign totaled $7.78 million, up 2 percent from last year.
snippet: Contributions to the 96th New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign totaled $7.78 million, up 2 percent from last year.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Feb. 8, the last day of the 96th New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign, contributions had totaled $7,635,259. That was nearly $4,000 lower than the amount raised the previous year.

abstract: My father’s midlife transition taught me that if life is about change, love is about constancy.
snippet: My father’s midlife transition taught me that if life is about change, love is about constancy.
lead_paragraph: “I won’t be mad,” I said to my boyfriend. “I’ll understand. Really.”

headline.main: When a Dad’s Secret Changes Everything
headline.print_headline: When a Dad’s Secret Changes Everything

abstract: An uncompromising approach, and not just to reporting in Vietnam.
snippet: An uncompromising approach, and not just to reporting in Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: ONE DAY IN EARLY JANUARY 1963, David Halberstam, portable typewriter in hand, appeared at the ground-floor apartment I was renting on a side street in Saigon. The front room served as an office. I slept in the second room at the back. I was the correspondent for United Press International, and David was in Vietnam for The New York Times. It was typical of the man that he did not ask, “May I join you?” Although wire-service reporters and daily-newspaper journalists often teamed up overseas, he simply assumed he would be welcome and set his typewriter down on the other side of the table I used as a desk. That day was the beginning of a partnership and, in later years after our assignments in Vietnam were over, a friendship that was to endure until he was killed in a car crash in California last April.

headline.main: The Combatant

abstract: A test of the tolerance of high school freshmen.
snippet: A test of the tolerance of high school freshmen.
lead_paragraph: One evening in the spring of my son Joseph’s freshman year in high school, he brought up something he said he’d been thinking over since the previous summer. “I really want to dye my hair purple,” he said.

abstract: The 72d Appeal    The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was established in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of The Times. That year, 117 contributors donated a total of $3,630.88 to be distributed among three private social- service agencies.   Since then the number of agencies has grown to eight, and the fund, which has raised millions of dollars, has helped tens of thousands of destitute people in the metropolitan area.

abstract: Lauren Fox article on deciding to marry man she loved, a Potestant-raised, atheist Irishman, even though she deeply wanted to marry a Jew in order to honor members of her family lost to Holocaust; drawing (M)
snippet: Lauren Fox article on deciding to marry man she loved, a Potestant-raised, atheist Irishman, even though she deeply wanted to marry a Jew in order to honor members of her family lost to Holocaust; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: I USED to have an imaginary Jewish boyfriend. I dreamed him up several years ago. He was a nice guy named Jeff who was a lawyer for the A.C.L.U., played classical guitar and wanted to have three kids. One year this imaginary Jewish boyfriend even accompanied me to Yom Kippur services, while my actual, Protestant-raised but nonbelieving Irish boyfriend stayed home and ate -- this is true -- a ham sandwich.

headline.main: When a Relationship Carries the Weight of History
headline.print_headline: MODERN LOVE; When a Relationship Carries the Weight of History

abstract: Nahid Rachlin article on being raised in Iran partly by aunt who doted on her and partly by a mother who was less affectionate; says her mother, who had five children, gave her when she was 6 to her sister in Tehran, who was childless; says that her father took her back to Ahvaz at age 9 and that her relationship with her mother was never to be as close as one she had with her aunt (M)
snippet: Nahid Rachlin article on being raised in Iran partly by aunt who doted on her and partly by a mother who was less affectionate; says her mother, who had five children, gave her when she was 6 to her sister in Tehran, who was childless; says that h...
lead_paragraph: Soon after my mother found out she was pregnant with me, she promised me to her sister, a widow with no children of her own. My father, who was traveling at the time, was told of her decision only when he returned. My mother had already given birth to seven children: two died; five lived. So when I was 6 months old, my grandmother, carrying a bottle of my mother's milk, took me on the arduous 14-hour train from Ahvaz, in the south of Iran, to Tehran, where my aunt lived.

headline.main: A Bitter Homecoming
headline.print_headline: LIVES; A Bitter Homecoming
